body: Implementation mostly taken from libsodium utils. Fix #347 --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/354)

comment_data.body: you might want to add `.user` to your gitignore

comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -204,7 +204,11 @@ apidsl(
   toxcore/crypto_core.api.h)
 add_module(toxcrypto
   toxcore/crypto_core.c
-  toxcore/crypto_core.h)
+  toxcore/crypto_core.h
+  toxcore/crypto_core_mem.c)
+include(CheckFunctionExists)
+CHECK_FUNCTION_EXISTS(explicit_bzero HAVE_EXPLICIT_BZERO)
+CHECK_FUNCTION_EXISTS(memset_s HAVE_MEMSET_S)

comment_data.body: `m` < `n` - sort includes. Also, while you're at it, add an empty line after the local includes block.

comment_regular_data.body: Just for reference, here is the relevant code section from libsodium https://github.com/jedisct1/libsodium/blob/9cae7b6b7c6f527df807157602ba48821281048b/src/libsodium/sodium/utils.c#L61-L132.
@Diadlo any reason why you didn't include the copyright and the license statements from libsodium? You are violating libsodium's licensing terms by copy-pasting the code like that.

@nurupo Sorry, I'm don't understand all "copyright and the license" stuff. Where I should paste copyright? It is what I should paste, isn't it?
```
/*
 * ISC License
 *
 * Copyright (c) 2013-2016
 * Frank Denis <j at pureftpd dot org>
 */
```

libsodium is licensed under ISC license https://github.com/jedisct1/libsodium/blob/master/LICENSE.

First off, if we want to include libsodium's code in toxcore, we need to make sure ISC is GPL-compatible, which is the case https://www.gnu.org/licenses/license-list.en.html#GPLCompatibleLicenses.

Now, we need to comply with the terms on the ISC license

> \* Permission to use, copy, modify, and/or distribute this software for any
> \* purpose with or without fee is hereby granted, provided that the above
> \* copyright notice and this permission notice appear in all copies.

So we need to include the copyright notice and the license statement. Not sue if saying that the original functions were licensed under ISC license is enough or we should include the whole license text though. I think something like:

>crypto_memcmp() and crypto_memzero() functions are taken from libsodium
> Copyright (c) 2013-2016 Frank Denis <j at pureftpd dot org>, ISC License

would be compliant with the ISC license. You could copy-paste the entire ISC license text to be really sure you comply with "this permission notice appear in all copies". The first line telling which functions were taken from where shouldn't be required, but I like to have it for clarity.

@iphydf what do you think?
@iphydf suggested placing the borrowed functions into a separate file, which would have the entire https://github.com/jedisct1/libsodium/blob/master/LICENSE as its header text. I like that idea.
Done
Where are `HAVE_EXPLICIT_BZERO` and `HAVE_MEMSET_S` defined? I believe libsodium's autotools build system defines those.
@nurupo Removed
Not sure if removing them in favor of the generic solution is a good idea.

@nurupo I found definition only [`HAVE_EXPLICIT_BZERO`](https://github.com/jedisct1/libsodium/blob/master/configure.ac#L678). I will create [quiestion-issue](https://github.com/jedisct1/libsodium/issues/463) to libsodium
@nurupo Done.
Fixed
Don't know whether the `CRYPTO_TEST_MEMCMP_EPS` constant is small enough, it might very well be, but other than that the tests look good.
Also, I don' think we need `extern "C" {` block in headers that are not public.

Without `extern "C" (` windows build was [failed](https://travis-ci.org/TokTok/c-toxcore/jobs/186697508#L1048)

`diff_same` ~ `diff_not_same` ~ 4250 on my PC, which is 10 times greater than `EPS`
Should I run many tests and calculate expected value for the current machine and variance?

>Without extern "C" ( windows build was failed

That's because the names collide. libsodium defines `sodium_memzero()` and we define it too. Having different linkage, C vs C++, removes this collision.

>diff_same ~ diff_not_same ~ 4250 on my PC, which is 10 times greater than EPS
Should I run many tests and calculate expected value for the current machine and variance?

I'm not knowledgeable in the proper way of checking if a function is constant time or not. The test looks good to me.
Sometimes `test_memcmp` fails (only for clang travis) with delta time `1000` or `2000`. I haven't any idea

Two things:

1. You'll want to use the distance, i.e. absolute difference, not the actual difference.
2. You'll probably want to compare the median time taken by each call, not the average difference.

@iphydf Yep, doing so will also fix the conflicting declaration issue mentioned in https://github.com/TokTok/c-toxcore/pull/354#issuecomment-269165839, as we won't be declaring our own `sodium_memzero()` and `sodium_memcpm()`, so we can drop that dirty `extern "C" (` hack. Not that I would have approved the PR with it anyway.
Wouldn't it be better to just remove the support for NaCl and use only libsodium?

*[auto_tests/crypto_test.c, line 342 at r4](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/354#-K_Bx9TWdUIE6kr75SRo:-K_Bx9TXkE15ffdG-YDQ:bmgpwzx) ([raw file](https://github.com/toktok/c-toxcore/blob/ce6334c413d2101c841b096ffdfbc43e9d52a05b/auto_tests/crypto_test.c#L342)):*
> ```C
> 
> #define CRYPTO_TEST_MEMCMP_SIZE 1024*1024
> #define CRYPTO_TEST_MEMCMP_COUNT 10
> ```

I suggest making this number a lot larger (by 1 or 2 orders of magnitude). If the test takes too long then, reduce the `MEMCMP_SIZE` number. Increasing the count makes the result more precise and less likely to flake.

---
